qas.question: When did the sacrifices to the deities of the heavens occur?
What color was the sacrifice mandated to be for heaven deities?
What type of sacrifices were offered to gods with earth connections?
What event was held after the sacrifice?
Who ate the meat of the sacrifice during the after sacrifice  banquet?

context: Sacrifice to deities of the heavens (di superi, "gods above") was performed in <a0_0>daylight<a0_0/>, and under the public gaze. Deities of the upper heavens required <a1_0>white<a1_0/>, infertile victims of their own sex: Juno a white heifer (possibly a white cow); Jupiter a white, castrated ox (bos mas) for the annual oath-taking by the consuls. Di superi with strong connections to the earth, such as Mars, Janus, Neptune and various genii – including the Emperor's – were offered <a2_0>fertile<a2_0/> victims. After the sacrifice, a <a3_0>banquet<a3_0/> was held; in state cults, the images of honoured deities took pride of place on banqueting couches and by means of the sacrificial fire consumed their proper portion (exta, the innards). Rome's <a4_0>officials and priests<a4_0/> reclined in order of precedence alongside and ate the meat; lesser citizens may have had to provide their own.
